StudyBible

High-Fidelity Biblical Exegesis with Original Language Analysis

Home Acts

Acts Chapter 10

Cornelius and Peter: The Gospel Opens to the Gentiles

Acts 10:1

Sacred Text

Ἀνὴρ δέ ⸀τις ἐν Καισαρείᾳ ὀνόματι Κορνήλιος, ἑκατοντάρχης ἐκ σπείρης τῆς καλουμένης Ἰταλικῆς,
Direct: Now a certain man in Caesarea, Cornelius by name, a centurion from the cohort being called the Italian,
English: There was a man in Caesarea named Cornelius, a centurion of what was known as the Italian Cohort.
Amplified: Now at that time, there was a particular man of significant standing living in the city of Caesarea, whose name was Cornelius. He held the military rank of a centurion, a commander of about one hundred soldiers, belonging to the specific regiment that was officially designated as the Italian Cohort.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

  • The narrative of Acts pivots to a new scene, introducing a specific individual.
  • This person is a man named Cornelius.
  • He is a Gentile, not a Jew by birth.
  • His residence is the city of Caesarea.
  • His profession is that of a Roman centurion.
  • His military unit is identified as the Italian Cohort.

Life Application

[object Object]

Acts 10:2

Sacred Text

εὐσεβὴς καὶ φοβούμενος τὸν θεὸν σὺν παντὶ τῷ οἴκῳ αὐτοῦ, ⸀ποιῶν ἐλεημοσύνας πολλὰς τῷ λαῷ καὶ δεόμενος τοῦ θεοῦ διὰ παντός,
Direct: pious and fearing God with all his household, doing many alms to the people and praying to God continually,
English: He was a devout man who feared God along with his whole household. He gave generously to the people and prayed regularly to God.
Amplified: This man was characterized by a genuine reverence and active piety, and he was one who lived in reverential awe of the one true God, a conviction he shared with his entire household; furthermore, he habitually and generously gave charitable gifts to the Jewish people and was continually petitioning God in prayer at all times.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

Life Application

[object Object]

Acts 10:3

Sacred Text

εἶδεν ἐν ὁράματι φανερῶς ὡσεὶ περὶ ὥραν ἐνάτην τῆς ἡμέρας ἄγγελον τοῦ θεοῦ εἰσελθόντα πρὸς αὐτὸν καὶ εἰπόντα αὐτῷ· Κορνήλιε.
Direct: He saw in a vision clearly, at about the ninth hour of the day, an angel of God having entered to him and having said to him: 'Cornelius.'
English: He distinctly saw in a vision at about the ninth hour of the day an angel of God who came in and said to him, 'Cornelius.'
Amplified: This man, Cornelius, while fully awake, saw in a vision that was objectively real and unmistakably clear, at approximately three o'clock in the afternoon, a customary time for Jewish prayer, a direct messenger sent from the one true God who physically entered into his presence and spoke directly to him, calling him by his personal name: Cornelius.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

  • The event is a historical fact, not a dream or subjective impression.
  • The subject, Cornelius, saw [εἶδεν (eiden)] a vision [ἐν ὁράματι (en horamati)] while he was awake.
  • The adverb [φανερῶς (phanerōs)] qualifies the vision as 'manifestly,' 'clearly,' or 'distinctly,' emphasizing its objective reality.
  • The vision's content was an [ἄγγελον τοῦ θεοῦ (angelon tou theou)], a 'messenger of God,' who physically appeared to enter the room.
  • The angel initiated direct, personal communication by speaking Cornelius's name.

Life Application

[object Object]

Acts 10:4

Sacred Text

ὁ δὲ ἀτενίσας αὐτῷ καὶ ἔμφοβος γενόμενος εἶπεν· Τί ἐστιν, κύριε; εἶπεν δὲ αὐτῷ· Αἱ προσευχαί σου καὶ αἱ ἐλεημοσύναι σου ἀνέβησαν εἰς μνημόσυνον ἔμπροσθεν τοῦ θεοῦ.
Direct: And the one having stared intently at him and having become terrified, said: 'What is it, lord?' And he said to him: 'Your prayers and your alms have ascended for a memorial before the face of God.'
English: And staring at him and becoming terrified, he said, “What is it, Lord?” And he said to him, “Your prayers and your alms have ascended as a memorial before God.”
Amplified: And Cornelius, gazing intently upon the angelic messenger and becoming utterly terrified by the supernatural sight, asked with reverent submission, 'What is it, my lord?' The angel then delivered the message to him, saying, 'The consistent pattern of your devout prayers and your compassionate acts of charity to the poor have together ascended and come up into the very presence of God, where they have been received as a formal memorial offering, prompting His divine attention and action.'

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

  • The event is a literal, historical encounter between a Roman centurion named Cornelius and an angel of God.
  • Cornelius [Κορνήλιος] (Kornēlios, from the Latin 'Cornelius,' possibly meaning 'horn'), a Roman centurion, experienced a genuine supernatural vision (Acts 10:3).
  • His reaction, staring intently [ἀτενίσας] (atenisas, 'to gaze fixedly') and becoming terrified [ἔμφοβος] (emphobos, 'filled with fear'), is a normative human response to a divine encounter (cf. Luke 1:12; Daniel 10:7-9).
  • He addresses the angel with a term of high respect, [κύριε] (kyrie), which can mean 'Sir' or 'Lord,' acknowledging a superior being.
  • The angel delivers a direct message from God.
  • The message states that two specific categories of Cornelius's actions—his prayers [προσευχαί] (proseuchai) and his alms [ἐλεημοσύναι] (eleēmosynai)—have 'ascended' [ἀνέβησαν] (anebēsan).
  • This ascent is not merely noted; it is registered εἰς μνημόσυνον (eis mnēmosynon), 'as a memorial,' directly in God's presence, ἔμπροσθεν τοῦ θεοῦ (emprosthen tou theou), 'before the face of God.'

Life Application

[object Object]

Acts 10:5

Sacred Text

καὶ νῦν πέμψον ⸂ἄνδρας εἰς Ἰόππην⸃ καὶ μετάπεμψαι Σίμωνά ⸂τινα ὃς ἐπικαλεῖται Πέτρος⸃·
Direct: And now, send men to Joppa and summon a certain Simon who is also called Peter.
English: Now send men to Joppa and call for Simon, whose surname is Peter.
Amplified: Therefore, at this very moment, you are to dispatch men immediately to the port city of Joppa, and you are to specifically summon to your presence a man named Simon, the one who is also known by the surname Peter.

Exegetical Synthesis

Life Application

Recognize that God's specific instructions often require us to step beyond our personal comfort zones and cross social, cultural, or racial barriers we have erected.,Respond to God's leading with immediate obedience, just as Cornelius did, even when you don't yet understand the full purpose or outcome.,Actively look for the 'divine appointments' God is orchestrating, where He brings you into contact with people from different backgrounds for the sake of the Gospel.,Confront and dismantle any personal prejudice or bias, asking God to give you His heart for all people, seeing them not by their external status but as individuals for whom Christ died.,Understand that your personal obedience to a specific, seemingly small command from God can be a critical link in the chain of His grand, redemptive plan for others.,Be a 'Peter' whom God can send, and be a 'Cornelius' who is willing to listen and seek—be prepared to both carry the message and to receive it in unexpected ways from unexpected people.

Acts 10:7

Sacred Text

ὡς δὲ ἀπῆλθεν ὁ ἄγγελος ὁ λαλῶν αὐτῷ, φωνήσας δύο τῶν οἰκετῶν καὶ στρατιώτην εὐσεβῆ τῶν προσκαρτερούντων αὐτῷ
Direct: And when the angel who was speaking to him departed, having called two of the household servants and a devout soldier from those who regularly attended him...
English: When the angel who spoke to him had departed, he called two of his household servants and a devout soldier from among his personal attendants.
Amplified: The very moment the angelic messenger who had been speaking directly to him had gone, Cornelius acted without delay, summoning two of his trusted servants from within his own household and a genuinely pious soldier, one of those who was steadfastly and loyally assigned to his immediate personal service.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

Life Application

[object Object]

Acts 10:8

Sacred Text

καὶ ἐξηγησάμενος ⸂ἅπαντα αὐτοῖς⸃ ἀπέστειλεν αὐτοὺς εἰς τὴν Ἰόππην.
Direct: And having explained everything to them, he sent them to Joppa.
English: After explaining everything to them, he sent them on their way to Joppa.
Amplified: And so, after he had narrated in full detail the entire sequence of events and the divine instructions he had received, Cornelius personally commissioned and dispatched these men on their mission to the port city of Joppa.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

  • This verse records the immediate, practical obedience of the Roman centurion, Cornelius, to the divine vision he received.
  • The core action is twofold: comprehensive communication followed by decisive delegation.
  • Cornelius receives a supernatural command from an angel of God (Acts 10:3-6).
  • His response is not delayed contemplation but faithful, prompt action.
  • He first fully explains the situation and the divine mandate to his chosen messengers.
  • He then sends them from Caesarea to Joppa to summon the Apostle Peter.
  • This verse functions as a narrative hinge, transitioning from divine revelation to human execution.

Life Application

[object Object]

Acts 10:9

Sacred Text

Τῇ δὲ ἐπαύριον ὁδοιπορούντων ἐκείνων καὶ τῇ πόλει ἐγγιζόντων ἀνέβη Πέτρος ἐπὶ τὸ δῶμα προσεύξασθαι περὶ ὥραν ἕκτην.
Direct: And on the next day, as they were journeying and drawing near to the city, Peter went up onto the housetop to pray, around the sixth hour.
English: The next day, as they were on their journey and approaching the city, Peter went up on the roof to pray, about noon.
Amplified: Now on the very next day, while the men sent from Cornelius were still traveling on the road and were just then drawing near to the city of Joppa, Peter himself went up onto the flat housetop, a customary place for privacy and contemplation, for the specific purpose of praying, at about the sixth hour, which corresponds to high noon.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

  • The event recorded is a literal, historical occurrence, meticulously documented by Luke.
  • It transpires on a specific day, Τῇ δὲ ἐπαύριον (tē de epaurion), 'on the next day,' linking it directly to the timeline of Cornelius's vision.
  • The narrative details two simultaneous, physical actions: the journey of Cornelius's men and the ascent of Peter.
  • A specific individual, Peter, is in a specific location, Joppa, in the house of Simon the Tanner.
  • He performs a deliberate action, ἀνέβη (anebē), 'he went up,' for a specific purpose, προσεύξασθαι (proseuxasthai), 'to pray.'
  • The time is precisely noted as περὶ ὥραν ἕκτην (peri hōran hektēn), 'around the sixth hour' or noon.
  • This detailed, factual account serves as the historical anchor for a supernatural revelation that will pivot the redemptive mission of the early Church.

Life Application

[object Object]

Acts 10:10

Sacred Text

ἐγένετο δὲ πρόσπεινος καὶ ἤθελεν γεύσασθαι· παρασκευαζόντων δὲ ⸀αὐτῶν ⸀ἐγένετο ἐπʼ αὐτὸν ἔκστασις,
Direct: And he became very hungry and was wishing to taste; and while they were preparing, a trance came upon him,
English: He became very hungry and wanted something to eat, and while the meal was being prepared, he fell into a trance.
Amplified: Then Peter became intensely hungry and for some time had been wanting to take a meal, and while the members of the household were in the process of preparing the food, a divinely initiated state of ecstasy fell upon him.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

  • The event is presented by Luke the historian as a literal, factual occurrence, not an allegory or parable.
  • Peter experienced a real, physical hunger at a specific time of day, the sixth hour or noon (Acts 10:9), the customary time for prayer and a meal.
  • This physical hunger served as the direct contextual trigger for the divine vision concerning food.
  • A supernatural state, a trance, overtook his physical senses while others were engaged in the mundane act of preparing a meal.

Life Application

Recognize that God often uses ordinary, physical circumstances—like hunger, work, or daily routines—as the stage for extraordinary spiritual revelation. Be attentive to Him in the mundane.,Your most deeply ingrained traditions, cultural biases, and personal 'unclean lists' may be the very things God wants to challenge to expand His kingdom through you. Be willing to have your paradigms shattered by His Word and Spirit.,True obedience requires moving beyond mere intellectual agreement with a new truth from God. Peter had to get up, travel to a Gentile's home, and eat with him. Application means action; it means 'doing' the Word.,When God gives a clear command that contradicts your comfort or tradition, do not hesitate. The salvation of others may be waiting on the other side of your obedience, just as it was for Cornelius and his household.

Acts 10:11

Sacred Text

καὶ θεωρεῖ τὸν οὐρανὸν ἀνεῳγμένον καὶ ⸀καταβαῖνον σκεῦός τι ὡς ὀθόνην μεγάλην τέσσαρσιν ⸀ἀρχαῖς καθιέμενον ἐπὶ τῆς γῆς,
Direct: and he beholds the heaven having been opened and descending a certain vessel like a great linen sheet by four corners being let down upon the earth,
English: He saw heaven opened and something like a great sheet descending, being let down to the earth by its four corners.
Amplified: And in this state of ecstatic trance, he intently gazed and saw the sky itself peeled open, and a particular object, some kind of container, was continuously descending, appearing much like an enormous sheet of linen cloth, which was being carefully lowered by its four terminating points down onto the surface of the land.

Exegetical Synthesis

Life Application

Examine your heart for any hidden prejudices or cultural barriers that cause you to categorize people as 'clean' or 'unclean,' acceptable or unacceptable.,Recognize that the Gospel of Jesus Christ has demolished every wall of hostility—racial, social, economic, or political—that we use to separate ourselves from others.,Be willing to have your most deeply-held traditions, personal preferences, and comfortable routines challenged and overturned by a clear command from God's Word.,Actively listen for God's call to engage with the 'Cornelius' in your world—the person or group of people outside your normal social circle whom God is calling you to reach with His love.,Understand that radical obedience to God may require you to step into situations that are culturally uncomfortable or violate man-made rules for the sake of proclaiming the truth.,Do not mistake the symbols of your faith for the substance. Your mission is not ultimately about rules or rituals, but about bringing all people from all corners of the world into a relationship with the living God.

Acts 10:12

Sacred Text

ἐν ᾧ ὑπῆρχεν πάντα τὰ τετράποδα ⸂καὶ ἑρπετὰ τῆς γῆς καὶ⸃ πετεινὰ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ.
Direct: in which were existing all the four-footed animals and creeping things of the earth and flying things of the sky.
English: In it were all kinds of four-footed animals, reptiles of the earth, and birds of the air.
Amplified: Contained within this vessel, there were present as an established collection all the four-footed beasts of the world, along with the creeping creatures of the land and the birds of the sky.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

  • The text describes a supernatural vision experienced by the Apostle Peter.
  • This vision is presented by Luke, the author of Acts, as a historical event, not an allegory or parable.
  • Peter saw a physical-appearing object, a great sheet, lowered from the sky.
  • Inside this sheet was a collection of animals representing the three major categories of non-aquatic life.
  • Crucially, this collection contained animals biblically designated as both 'clean' and 'unclean' under the Mosaic Law, with no distinction made between them.

Life Application

[object Object]

Acts 10:13

Sacred Text

καὶ ἐγένετο φωνὴ πρὸς αὐτόν· Ἀναστάς, Πέτρε, θῦσον καὶ φάγε.
Direct: And a voice came to him: 'Having risen, Peter, slaughter and eat.'
English: And a voice came to him, 'Rise, Peter; kill and eat.'
Amplified: Then a voice came directly to him, issuing a sequence of authoritative commands: Rise up to your feet, Peter; now, you must slaughter these animals for food and then you are to eat.

Exegetical Synthesis

Life Application

The command to Peter is a command to the Church today: identify the 'unclean' categories you have created. These are the people, groups, cultures, or social strata you have been conditioned to avoid, judge, or deem 'common' or unworthy of the Gospel.,We must 'Rise' from our complacency and comfort zones. This requires a conscious decision to move out from what is familiar and safe into territory we might consider spiritually or culturally foreign.,We must 'kill' our prejudices, traditions, and fears that create barriers to fellowship and evangelism. This means putting to death the pride, fear of man, and false piety that keep us separated from those Jesus died to save.,We must 'eat,' which means to have full fellowship with and actively welcome all people into the Body of Christ. It is not enough to tolerate from a distance; we are called to bring them into our homes, our churches, and our lives, sharing the bread of life as one family in Christ. What God has cleansed in the blood of Jesus, we must never again call unclean.

Acts 10:14

Sacred Text

ὁ δὲ Πέτρος εἶπεν· Μηδαμῶς, κύριε, ὅτι οὐδέποτε ἔφαγον πᾶν κοινὸν ⸀καὶ ἀκάθαρτον.
Direct: But Peter said: By no means, Lord, because never have I eaten anything common and unclean.
English: But Peter said, 'By no means, Lord; for I have never eaten anything that is common or unclean.'
Amplified: But Peter, in a moment of visceral and devout protest, declared, 'Absolutely not, my Lord, because not once in my entire lifetime have I ever consumed anything that is ceremonially profane or ritually impure.'

Exegetical Synthesis

Life Application

Our sincerest devotion and long-held traditions, while often good, can sometimes become barriers to what God wants to do next. We must examine our own hearts for any 'By no means, Lord' responses to His leading, especially when He calls us to cross cultural, social, or personal boundaries we have erected. God is fundamentally concerned with people. The rules of separation in the Old Testament were meant to point to a greater holiness that is now found in Christ. Our application, therefore, is not to create new rules of separation, but to actively dismantle the unbiblical walls of prejudice, preference, and fear that keep us from sharing the Gospel with those we might consider 'unclean' or 'other'. Identify a person or group of people that your background, culture, or comfort zone has taught you to avoid. Pray for God to give you His heart for them, just as He did for Peter. Then, take one practical step this week to cross that boundary—initiate a conversation, share a meal, or offer a kindness—as a direct act of obedience to the God who cleanses all who come to Him through Christ.

Acts 10:15

Sacred Text

καὶ φωνὴ πάλιν ἐκ δευτέρου πρὸς αὐτόν· Ἃ ὁ θεὸς ἐκαθάρισεν σὺ μὴ κοίνου.
Direct: And a voice again for a second time to him: What things God has cleansed, you must not make common.
English: And the voice came to him again a second time, 'What God has made clean, do not call common.'
Amplified: Then a voice from heaven spoke directly to him once more, for the second time, with a clear and binding command: The very things which God Himself has pronounced ritually pure and ceremonially clean, you must immediately stop regarding or designating as unholy, profane, or defiled.

Exegetical Synthesis

Life Application

The core application is to actively identify and dismantle any personal prejudice, cultural bias, or religious tradition that causes you to label a person or group of people as 'unclean,' 'unworthy,' or 'common.',Recognize that God's cleansing work through the blood of Christ is definitive and absolute. If God has declared someone clean by calling them to Himself, you have no authority to contradict Him with your own standards.,Therefore, stop avoiding people you have been conditioned to see as 'other.' Intentionally build relationships and share the fellowship of the Gospel with those outside your social, economic, racial, or political circles.,Be obedient to the Holy Spirit's prompting, even when it challenges your deepest-held comforts, traditions, and fears, just as Peter was commanded to do. God's command to 'go' often requires us to first abandon our internal categories of 'don't go.'

Acts 10:16

Sacred Text

τοῦτο δὲ ἐγένετο ἐπὶ τρίς, καὶ ⸀εὐθὺς ἀνελήμφθη τὸ σκεῦος εἰς τὸν οὐρανόν.
Direct: And this occurred for a third time, and immediately the vessel was taken up into heaven.
English: This happened three times, and then the object was immediately taken back up into heaven.
Amplified: This entire visionary sequence unfolded a total of three times for absolute certainty, and then, without any delay, the vessel itself was supernaturally lifted up and received back into the sky from which it came.

Exegetical Synthesis

Literal-Primary Filter

  • The text records a visionary event experienced by the Apostle Peter while in a state of trance (Acts 10:10).
  • The vision of a vessel descending and ascending occurred three distinct times in succession.
  • Immediately following the third occurrence, the object, described as a 'skeuos' or vessel, was withdrawn back into heaven.
  • This is not a parable, but a divine revelation presented to Peter as a factual, perceptual experience to communicate a specific truth.

Life Application
